title: Which NFL quarterback will throw for the most touchdowns in the 2020 regular season?
preds: Heading into the final week of the season, Aaron Rodgers has a 6 TD lead (44) over second place Patrick Mahomes and Russell Wilson (38). Tom Brady is in fourth with 36 touchdowns and would need to throw for 8 in his next game. The NFL record for touchdown passes in a game is 7, meaning he is out based on past statistics. Mahomes has nothing to play for, with the Chiefs having clinched the AFC regular season title and a first round bye so he will most likely be sitting. Russell Wilson and the Seahawks still have a shot at the #1 seed in the NFC, as do the Packers, so I expect both QBs to play. Unless a major statistical anomaly occurs (Rodgers throws for 0 TDs - only occurred once this year) and Wilson throws for at least 6, maybe 7 (which would be an NFL record he would tie) to pass Rodgers, Rodgers is the winner. In fact, Wilson has only thrown for 5 TDs in a game twice this season, and that was weeks 2 and 3 before defenses started figuring out their tactics.
RODGERS has a 6 TD lead on Wilson and Mahomes... 8 on Brady. All have clinched playoff berths so I don't expect any of them to play the entire game in Week 17.
Moving a little closer to the 'crowd' forecast for now

Rodgers holds a few records:
"Most touchdown passes per game average, regular season: 2.072, Aaron Rodgers, (404 TD passes/195 games), 2008–2020.
Most seasons, 35+ passing touchdowns: 5, Aaron Rodgers, 2011–2012, 2014, 2016, 2020
Most seasons, 40+ passing touchdowns: 3, Aaron Rodgers, 2011, 2016, 2020
Most consecutive passing touchdowns, no interceptions, home: 49, Aaron Rodgers" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_National_Football_League_records_%28individual%29#Passing_touchdowns

As the season has progressed Rogers has taken the lead with 40 TD passes so far which gives him a 3 TD pass completion lead on Wilson.   
https://www.espn.com/nfl/stats/player/_/table/passing/sort/passingTouchdowns/dir/desc

Adjusting again, it seems as though if everyone gets their average, Rodgers will win easily. Both teams have about the same level of difficulty for the rest of the season between Seattle and Green Bay, so I don't see Wilson making up for the three TD deficit. It is still possible that Mahomes will surprise us all, but he is projected to have 41 TD passes this year. Wilson is projected to have 42, and Rodgers is projected to have 46. It depends on how this next week goes. If anyone closes the gap I will reassess, but it is more likely that I will go all in on Rodgers next week.
With only two games left, it seems unlikely that anyone will surpass Aaron Rodgers.
Only one TD pass today for Wilson. https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/seattle-seahawks-washington-football-team-20201220028/
Updating after the games this week.

Rodgers dead on again with 3 passing TDs. Wilson out-performed his average to make up for last week. He had 4. That leaves him behind by 3 still, though, and those 4 came against the Jets, which we figured he'd smoke. Again, I think this is a Rodgers/Wilson race now. There's (WAY OUTSIDE) chance that Mahomes goes absolutely crazy over the next three weeks and outperforms Rodgers, but I doubt it.

Through Week 14, barring any injuries. BRADY - 30 - projected finish is still 37 MAHOMES - 33 - projected total is 39 or 40 RODGERS - 39 - projected finish is 46 WILSON - (added 4) - 36 - projected finish is 42 or 43. WILSON faces the toughest pass defenses in the last 3 games and BRADY the easiest, but the hill is too steep to climb unless there are a lot of injuries. MAHOMES & RODGERS face about equal defenses, but 6 TDs is a lot to make up in 3 weeks.
This is not a forecasting question. This is gambling.
Updated based on spreading the 100% throughout the players... also with the season going by Rogers has pulled ahead as a favorite to have the most TDs
Forecast updated to reflect an expanded Rodgers' (name spelled incorrectly in the graph) lead, with Wilson and Mahomes still in striking distance.  4 games to play!

Aaron Rogers with 36 passing TDs and a 68.9 CMP % is currently in the lead supported by a strong offense that will carry him into continued success.  Wilson with 32 TDs and a better CMP% at 70 could pass Rogers if only supported by a strong offense, but alas his pass protection and receivers are getting worse this year, not better. Due to his talent, I hold Wilson at #2.  Mahomes and Brady are close but not likely to pass Rogers this year.

One more set of games and Rodgers is killing the competition. He hit is average on the dot this weekend, throwing for another three touchdowns. Wilson fell further behind, falling short of his average and throwing only one. Mahomes only threw one as well. Both will have a tough time catching up, even if Rodgers slows down.  I'm taking Brady and "Another" off the board completely, and decrementing Wilson and Mahomes. Wilson has a chance to throw some TDs against some pretty poor competition coming up, but that also means he likely won't have to. I forecast that it's Rodgers's to lose.

Rodgers (- correct spelling, BTW -) jumps ahead but has three usually-cold weather December games upcoming. (https://www.espn.com/nfl/team/schedule/_/name/gb) 
FWIW the December temperature forecast for the Wisconsin region projects as generally above-average, with below average precip.: https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/predictions/long_range/lead14/

Seattle will now be facing some higher-rated pass defenses (yards-per-game): https://www.espn.com/nfl/stats/team/_/view/defense/stat/passing/table/passing/sort/netPassingYardsPerGame/dir/asc https://www.espn.com/nfl/stats/player/_/table/passing/sort/passingTouchdowns/dir/desc
Updating after the games this week. Still 3 more to go before the week is done, but the teams in question are finished.

Through Week 13 (less Mon/Tues games) - barring any injuries... BRADY - had a bye, has 28 - projected finish is 37 MAHOMES - added 1 against a tough DEN D - at 31, projected total is now 40 RODGERS added 3 - current project total is still 45 WILSON added 1 against NYG - at 32, projected to finish with 41 OTHER - Roethlisberger has 25 with 5 games to play - a good game tonight against WASH brings him in line with BRADY. A couple of wild ones could end the season against CIN, IND, and CLE - so just keeping him on the radar for now. WILSON will faced the toughest pass defenses in the last 4 games; RODGERS the second toughest. BRADY has the easiest but the largest margin to overcome.

Running my simulations updated with the past week of data and now with only four weeks remaining, sees Rogers winning 88% of the time, Wilson 10%, Mahomes 2%, Brady <1%. I'll up Mahomes odd for his form lately, a decrease Russell's similarly.

Rodgers retains a 3 TD lead with 3 weeks remaining in the season.  Mahomes has 2 top 10 defenses left to face and is averaging 7.1% TD's/Pass vs Rodgers 8.7% with roughly the same pass attempts.  Russel wilsons play continues to be suboptimal with a 1 TD performance in week 13 and Brady is back 5 TDs with 3 weeks to go, meaning he needs to average 2 TD/game more than Rodgers, which has not happened this season at any point.  https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2020/passing.htm#passing::pass_td

As of today, stats as follows: Tom Brady: 28 (2.3/gm)
Patrick Mahomes: 30 (2.7/gm)
Aaron Rogers: 33 (3/gm)
Russell Wilson: 31 (2.8)
Another: Rothlisberger (25, 2.3/gm) AND Deshaun Watson (24, 2.2/gm) Each has 5 games left, save Brady, who only has 4. If the averages hold, Rogers looks like he's the runaway fave with 48, though Mahomes isn't super far behind at 43.5 and Wilson is right there with 45.  Of note, Watson's been *killing* it in the last 6 games, with something like 200 passes thrown without a pick. That said, he'd have a *lot* of ground to make up, and they have to play the Titans and the Colts twice (though the Bears and the Bengals might give up some TDs). So what about the inside view for Rogers? They have the Panthers (ick), the Bears (ick), Eagles (ick), Lions (ick) and Titans (not bad) left to play. Rogers is likely to keep throwing TDs against that lot.  Inside for Wilson - Giants (ick), Jets (super ick), Washington (ick), Rams (decent), and niners (ick). Likely to keep throwing TDs here as well.  Inside view for Mahomes - Broncos (ick), Dolphins (ick-ish), Saints (that's gonna be a tough one), Chargers (ick), and Falcons (ick-ish). Mahomes will likely amass some pretty good stats, but he might just as well get a few more rushing TDs that Rogers would pick up as passing TDs.  If we're comparing the skeds head-to-head, Rogers has the easier road. Wilson has the easiest of the three, but he's sitting 2 behind Rogers right now and averaging slightly less per game. I think he has a decent shot to catch him, but it's not a lock. The one thing that gives me pause here is passing attempts per game. Generally, if the quarterback is making more attempts, they might just have a few more opportunities for their receivers to break one and put it in the end zone. This is also indicative of a team that might get down a lot and HAVE to score with passing TDs, which gives the QB more opportunities to pad the stats. Here, Tom Brady tops the list w/ 474, but of course he has an extra game under his belt. Rothlisberger is right behind him with 431 attempts so far, and Mahomes has 423 already. Wilson has 393 and Rogers isn't even on the list. SO! There may be an opportunity for a few more dogs' asses to get the sun shined on them. Be that as it may, all we're doing here is trying to figure out who will have the *MOST*, not by how *much* that QB will win.  SO! I'm putting most of my eggs in the Rogers and Wilson baskets. Rogers is already in front and has a pretty nice schedule. Mahomes might get close, but he might run a few in too, and his schedule is *slightly* more challenging. Brady might get desperate needing to get a playoff berth, so he might be put in a position to throw a few more, but he's pretty far behind. I feel pretty good about him not catching up. That leaves Wilson, who might be pushing to get a first place finish, but then so might the Packers. I'll be interested to come back here on Tuesday and see where we're at. I'm betting my number on Rogers just keeps going up.
Based on current standings of TDs thrown, strength of defenses left to face, and the distance between these quarterbacks and the remainder of the field in terms of TDs.

Percentages adjusted to reflect the fact that Aaron Rodgers took the lead in TD passes in the most recent game week.  He threw 4 TDs in his game against the bears... Wilson only threw 1 TD pass in his most recent outing.  Rodgers now leads by 2 TDs over Wilson, and 3 over Mahomes.  Tom Brady is now 5 TDs off the pace.
Chiefs are headed to the superbowl(ish); whenever that happens.

Chiefs, Packers, and Seahawks are gunning for the bye, but Seahawks have the toughest schedule, so Wilson won't make it. Packers have a pretty easy one, so highest odds there. Mahomes may make a late-season push to solidify MVP and grab the bye.
Young quarterback looking to upset the GOAT.

Patrick Mahomes broke the NFL touchdown pass record in October 2020 and appears to be throwing more this season instead of running (which he's really good at).  With that, I predict Mahomes will throw for the most touchdowns.

Updating through Week 12 (other than the Wed afternoon game) and assuming all stay healthy. BRADY picked up 3 but goes into the bye week - 4 games remaining against the weakest pass defense of the 4 QBs listed; currently has 28 - projected total 37. MAHOMES picked up 3 against TAM and should get at least 2 per game - at 30; projected total is still 41 RODGERS got 4 against CHI and has 5 games left - at 33, should get 2 per game and maybe 3 against DET and TEN - projected total is now 45 WILSON managed 1 against PHI and faces the toughest defense of the 4 QBs listed - including WASH who has held opponents under 200 pypg and LAR who is allowing 1.00 ptd/g - at 31 currently, projected total is now 42

My prediction method is as follows: I take each of the quarterback's data on td passes this year, and compute a mean and a variance based on then. Then I simulate the final 5 games of the season for each, where I draw the number of tds they throw from that distribution. Then I determine which of the qb's has the most tds for each simulation.  The results:
Rodgers: 65%
Wilson: 25%
Mahomes: 10% 
Brady: <1% I think this makes it clear that Brady and the rest of the NFL qbs are just too far behind. This method overrates Wilson a bit because he has a high variance, though most of that success was in the beginning of the year and his TD totals have declined in recent weeks. As a result, I'll give more to Mahomes, who I deem most likely to catch Rogers.  All of the teams seem to have pretty easy schedules the rest of the way. Maybe Rogers has a little more difficult weather wise, by KC and Seattle can be brutal.
Need another game or so to better sort-out the top three QBs.  FWIW, Green Bay has four potential cold/snowy-weather games scheduled in Dec. https://www.espn.com/nfl/team/schedule/_/name/gb

1. Rogers has 33 TDs so far with a 85.2 QBR. Seemingly, his best year since 2011. Expect him to throw the most. 60%. 
2. Patrick Mahomes has 30 TDs with an 86.2 QBR. He seems to have been heating up lately. Given the excellent Chiefs O-Line compared to the Seahawks I expect him to throw more TDs. 20% Chance.
3. Wilson has 30 TDs so far with a 74.2 QBR. Has had a good number of TDs, but also lots of sacks and INTs. His performance over the last three weeks has been much poorer after a strong start to the season because of a weakening of the Seahawks O-line. He could come back to throw the most TDs given he has 6 more games vs. either 5 or 4 for all others listed, but this is unlikely. 15%
4. Brady has 28 TDs so far with a 69.7 QBR. He is still the GOAT, but he is clearly playing in his twilight. He has 11 Interceptions and 16 sacks. He will still post 35 TDs or so, but he will not post the most for the season especially given TB only has 4 more games vs. 5 for all other teams listed. (5%)  
5. The only other possible QBs (Rothlisberger, Watson, Tannehill) are all behind Rodgers by 9 or more TDs as of Week 12 on Monday. It is very unlikely they will catch up. ( < 1%)

With Drew Brees being out for an extended period of time, Patrick Mahomes is the likely front-runner to walk away with this title. Aaron Rodgers is a very close second with the weapons he has around him and the scheme run by Green Bay. That said, Mahomes is more talented, accurate and mobile which makes him more likely to lead the NFL in passing touchdowns

No other QB is within 6 of these 4, with 5 games remaining they would need to average 1.2 TDs/game more than the 4 leaders. Russell Wilson accumulated the majority of his TD's in the first half of the season and has since been averaging fewer TD/GM than the other three. The chiefs face 2 top 10 defenses in terms of points allowed, putting Mahomes's chances slightly down.  Rodgers only faces 1 top 10 defense and 3 bottom 10. https://www.espn.com/nfl/stats/player/_/table/passing/sort/passingTouchdowns/dir/desc
https://www.espn.com/nfl/stats/team/_/view/defense/table/passing/sort/totalPointsPerGame/dir/asc

Since Wilson, Rogers, and Mahomes are all within 1 and 3TD from each other it is too close to tell a definitive projected winner. Looking at the remaining schedules and average Passing TD given up per game for the remaining teams you can simulate what the end of year stats might look like. I did not take into account the Standard deviation of average TDs per game per QB and eliminate any outlier games this year for the QBs.

Seahawks have the weakest remaining schedule in the NFL.   Russell Wilson currently leads by 1 TD pass over Aaron Rodgers and by 3 TDs over Patrick Mahomes.  Tom Brady is currently 5 TD passes behind.  This forecast is particularly tough because starting QBs in the NFL (as opposed to college) will begin to see reduced snaps in the final two games if playoff spots are locked up.  With that being said, based on current standing, Russell Wilson's Seahawks are unlikely to lock up the division before the final two weeks.  Aaron Rodger's Packers on the other hand are up two games in their division....thereby presenting a real possibility that Rodgers takes fewer snaps in the 16th game.  The 1% "other QB" accounts for the potential outlier (in this case, Big Ben, who is currently listed as "questionable" for his next start...)

Doing a quick analysis of the following players we can see their average amount of touchdowns over the last 6 season. Mahomes is an outlier because he only has two previous seasons to look at. These are the top 5 QB's for touchdowns according to https://www.teamrankings.com/nfl/player-stat/passing-touchdowns Rogers: average 32.8 touchdowns
Wilson: average 32 touchdowns
Mahomes: average 44.5 touchdowns*
Brady: average 35.3 touchdowns
Roethlisberger: average 25.6 touchdowns Due to Mahomes' short timeline it is hard to find his data as reliable... If this was his average across 6 season then I would predict he will have the most again, but it is not. Brady is the second highest average in the last years, but his recent change in teams makes me think his touchdown completion will drop off this year, which is already supported in that he only has 25 touchdowns this season so far. Compare that to Rogers with 29, Wilson with 30, and Mahomes with 27.  I think it is a very close call between Roger and Wilson, but in the end I think Wilson will have the most touchdowns. He is currently ahead of Rogers by 1, and the remaining season looks promising for him to keep that lead... But of course, as we all know, anything can happen of any given Sunday (hence why their percentages are so close.

I went with my own research before looking at the group, which is kind of in line with what I am saying, but a bit more in favor of Wilson, so I am upping my number a bit for Wilson.  Statistics from NFL show that Wilson is leading, but only by one. With the next few games being ones that I expect will result in Seattle scoring a few more times than usual since it is a lighter part of their schedule, I will say that Wilson has a good chance of coming out on top.  Meant to add the link last time as well. 
https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2020/passing.htm#passing::pass_td

Statistics from NFL show that Wilson is leading, but only by one. With the next few games being ones that I expect will result in Seattle scoring a few more times than usual since it is a lighter part of their schedule, I will say that Wilson has a good chance of coming out on top.

Updating through week 11. All TDs/game relate to passing only. BRADY picked up 2 against LAR, but only has 5 games left versus 6 for the other contenders - currently at 25, projected to finish with 36 MAHOMES picked up 2 against LV and plays some stingy defenses the next 3 games that are allowing less than 2 TDs/game (TAM, DEN, MIA) - currently at 27, projected to finish with 41 RODGERS picked up 3 against a stingy IND defense that was allowing less than 1.5 TDs/game. Every team the rest of this season is averaging under 2 TDs allowed per game. Currently 29, projected to finish with 42. WILSON picked up 2 against ARZ and also will face 6 teams that average under 2 TDs allowed per game including LAR who is allowing only 1.1 PTD/game. - currently at 30, projected to finish with 44

I don't think it will be Mahomes, Easily the hardest schedule (Tampa, Saints, etc). Seahawks have (Jets, Philly, Giants, Washington)
Green Bay's is pretty easy (Lions, Panthers, Eagles)
Brady has a chance with 4 poor defences at the end of the season. (2x Atlanta, Detroit, Minnesota) but is a couple  behind Russ and Aaron.

Russell Wilson has averaged 3 TD passes per game where the other 3 QBs have averaged less.  Additionally Wilson leads the other QBs by 4 TDs at this point which provides a little buffer.  Aaron Rogers could catchup therefore I give him a 15% chance.

As of now all QBs are assumed to stay healthy for the rest of the season. BRADY has already played 10 games and has 23 PTDs. All other QBs have one additional game remaining. I don't see more than 2 per game against LAR, LC, MIN, or DET. I could see 3 or more in both games versus ATL, but that won't be enough to pull him ahead... but after all, he is Tom Brady. Projected total finish - 36 MAHOMES (25)  will make this interesting as he ends the season with NO, ATL, and LAC where he could get 3 or more. The balance of the schedule looks likes 1 or 2 (average 2). Projected total finish - 41 or 42 RODGERS (26) has his best shot at getting 3 or more TDs against DET and TEN. I think the balance of the season will be an average of 2 per game. Projected total finish - 41 WILSON leads the pack with 28. He has the benefit of playing ARZ, NYG, and NYJ left. Assuming 3 per game in those plus a little over 2 per game in the remainder (SF or WAS could yield more than a pair) that would put him at a project total finish of 44. SEA seems to have the easiest path the rest of they way, but may be playing to win the NFC West in Week 17 whereas KC and GB may elect to rest the starters if they can maintain the current cushion they have in their divisions.
russ got an easy rest of the schedule and is already ahead

-- FWIW, looking back to 2019 Wilson was third in TD passes while the other guys listed in the question trailed further behind. (https://www.espn.com/nfl/stats/player/_/season/2019/seasontype/2/table/passing/sort/passingTouchdowns/) -- Wilson's Seahawks team and Mahomes' Chiefs currently rank in the top five in total yards and in passing. Teams for others listed do not, though Green Bay is sixth in passing. https://www.espn.com/nfl/stats/_/view/team -- Wilson has not played as well recently and there is some talk of running the ball more: https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/seahawks/with-carlos-hyde-healthier-and-russell-wilson-struggling-will-the-seahawks-go-old-school-vs-cardinals/ -- Seahawks' upcoming schedule 'on paper' does not look especially difficult:  https://www.espn.com/nfl/team/schedule/_/name/sea. 
Also, three of the final four Packer games are at home, likely in some December winter weather. ..All of that noted this question may still prove a close race between (at least) the top-listed three or four QBs. COVID-19 can always potentially sideline a player (or team) for a game or so.  Giving Wilson a slight edge for now.
When your defense is garbage, you have to outscore the competition.
Brady and Roger's are great QBs but their heydays are in the rear mirror. Russell likes to scramble more than Mahomes so I'm going with the latter. There's always an outside chance it's A N Other.
